In the event of an emergency involving the Bay City Terminal butane blending system, it is the policy of the Facility to initially contact the Bangor Township Fire Department and request their assistance. The Facility's emergency response plans are coordinated (annually) with the Bangor Township Fire Department and Bay County Emergency Management to maintain a relationship with first responders. Tours and drills with members of local emergency response organizations are held routinely (annually at a minimum.) These tours and drills enable the public emergency responders to become familiar with the hazards, equipment, resources and personnel in the Terminal. The Bangor Township Fire Department has participated in the initial PSM/RMP training session for this system.

E. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

MPLX is continually striving to make the Bay City Terminal the safest and most reliable workplace possible for its employees, neighbors and community.

In an effort to improve and promote system safety, MPLX looks for, and seeks employee input, on process safety improvements.  All process safety events (as defined in API 754) are electronically recorded, reviewed, and investigated via root-cause analysis (ex. TapRooT), as appropriate.  The Bangor Township Fire Department is contacted regarding participation in site emergency response training, coordination, and/or drills.  Additionally, MPLX will work cooperatively with the community to address any concerns.

Safety at the Facility depends upon the manner in which butane is handled as well as the various safety devices incorporated into the design of the process. Furthermore, comprehensive training is provided to employees, which reinforces the safety policies and procedures of the Bay City Terminal.

The facility has fixed inventories of butane. Butane is received by truck (transports) and stored in one (1) 90,000-gallon storage vessel. Specifically, liquefied butane is off-loaded by truck for storage under pressure. The butane is pumped to a blending skid for direct injection into regular and premium unleaded gasoline lines feeding the site gasoline truck-loading rack or on-site product storage tanks. Injection quantities are controlled via the blending skid and Bartec-Benke Analyzer. Process safety controls include excess flow valves, low-melting point (<250 degrees fahrenheit) feeds to pneumatic valves (fail closed), 85% fill shutoff on the vessel, emergency shut-off devices on the system and video display terminal, line thermal (pressure) reliefs, and grounding/interlock devices. Access to the Bay City Terminal is restricted to authorized employees, management personnel and authorized contractors/visitors.

B. GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION MEASURES

Our accidental release prevention and emergency planning/response programs help the Bay City Terminal effectively manage the hazards posed by our regulated substances to our employees, the public, and the environment. The covered process is regulated by the EPA RMP regulation 40 CFR Part 68, as well as the OSHA Process Safety Management standard 29CFR 1910.119. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RELEASE POLICIES

MPLX (Marathon) - Bay City Terminal is a refined petroleum product distributor. The Bay City Terminal is an onshore, light products, bulk petroleum storage terminal used for the storage and distribution of petroleum products to retail and commercial end-users in the vicinity of Bay City, MI. The Terminal handles and stores various grades of unleaded gasoline, low-sulfur diesel, No. 2 fuel oil, butane, ethanol, and various other petroleum-based additives.

MPLX - Bay City Terminal in Bay City, MI is committed to operating and maintaining  processes in a safe, reliable and environmentally sound manner. Marathon believes that excellent performance in health, safety, and the environment goes hand in hand with operating reliably, and that outstanding HES performance is of paramount importance.

The Bay City Terminal is designed, operated and maintained in a manner that protects the environment, as well as the health and safety of its employees, contractors and the community. Marathon promotes health, safety, and the environment through programs of awareness, compliance, prevention and protection. These programs include a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning. This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that Marathon has designed and implemented including:

B. An overview of the accidental release prevention programs;
C. A five-year accident history for accidental releases of reulated chemicals;
D. An overview of the emergency response program; and
E. An overview of planned changes to improve safety.
